articles.headline: Not a Jolly Season for 2 Top Bankers
articles.snippet: Despite a very bad year, the chiefs of both Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley are holding on to their power.
articles.abstract: Despite a very bad year, the chiefs of both Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley are holding on to their power.
articles.lead_paragraph: James E. Cayne and John J. Mack have a lot in common. The chiefs of both Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley have presided over announcements of steep losses this week and have forgone bonuses.

articles.headline: China Grabs West’s Smoke-Spewing Factories
articles.snippet: In its rush to recreate the industrial revolution that made the West rich, China has absorbed most of the major industries that once made the West dirty.
articles.abstract: In its rush to recreate the industrial revolution that made the West rich, China has absorbed most of the major industries that once made the West dirty.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANDAN, China  When residents of this northern Chinese city hang their clothes out to dry, the black fallout from nearby Handan Iron and Steel often sends them back to the wash.
articles.byline: By Joseph Kahn and Mark Landler

articles.headline: TV’s Perfect Girl Is Pregnant; Real Families Talk
articles.snippet: News of the pregnancy of Jamie Lynn Spears brought the subject of teenage pregnancy and sex suddenly into the air for mothers and daughters and fathers, too.
articles.abstract: News of the pregnancy of Jamie Lynn Spears brought the subject of teenage pregnancy and sex suddenly into the air for mothers and daughters and fathers, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, Mass.  Talk about teachable moments.

articles.headline: Personal Touch for Richardson in Envoy Role
articles.snippet: The Democratic presidential candidate is known for practicing diplomacy as contact sport.
articles.abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate is known for practicing diplomacy as contact sport.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1998, Bill Richardson, then the United States ambassador to the United Nations, flew to Japan in search of backing for potential military strikes in Iraq.

articles.headline: Solving the Mortgage Crisis May Require a Guardian Angel
articles.snippet: The Fed’s newly proposed rules might have prevented the current mess, but enacting them now will do nothing to repair the damage.
articles.abstract: The Fed’s newly proposed rules might have prevented the current mess, but enacting them now will do nothing to repair the damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: I knew it was the Christmas season. There on television was Henry F. Potter, the mean banker, quizzing Pa Bailey, the idealist from the building and loan society.

articles.headline: Data About Zetia Risks Was Not Fully Revealed
articles.snippet: New evidence shows that drug makers Merck and Schering-Plough never published several studies that raised questions about a cholesterol drug’s risks to the liver.
articles.abstract: New evidence shows that drug makers Merck and Schering-Plough never published several studies that raised questions about a cholesterol drug’s risks to the liver.
articles.lead_paragraph: New evidence shows that the drug makers Merck and Schering-Plough have conducted several studies of their popular cholesterol medicine Zetia that raise questions about its risks to the liver, but the companies have never published those results.

articles.headline: Sallie Mae Delays Stock Repurchase
articles.snippet: SLM, the parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion.
articles.abstract: SLM, the parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion as the bet has gone drastically wrong. On Thursday it negotiated a two-month delay in the deadline for coming up with the money.

articles.headline: A Revisionist Tale: Why a Poor China Seems Richer
articles.snippet: New calculations by the World Bank suggest China may not be so rich after all, and could deflate arguments for a need to revalue the yuan.
articles.abstract: New calculations by the World Bank suggest China may not be so rich after all, and could deflate arguments for a need to revalue the yuan.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Should China be treated differently because it may not be so rich after all? That is one of the central questions raised by new calculations from the World Bank that suggest the Chinese economy may not be as large as previously thought.
